remarks.para: The sequence is subscribed to first, followed by the sequence on another thread. This order of subscription avoids a certain race condition that could otherwise allow an element that no longer exists to be added anyway, without receiving a corresponding Remove notification from the sequence.

The sequence is used to populate the initial state of the collection, under the assumption that the sequence does not provide notifications for elements that are considered to already exist; however, it may provide notifications for existing elements after it provides corresponding notifications for those elements, thus the sequence is processed concurrently while the collection is being populated by the sequence.
The sequence is given precedence for all race conditions and conflicts while the collection is being populated by the sequence. This process is referred to as reconciliation.

Reconciliation ends when either of the two sequences completes. It also ends upon the first notification to be received, because this indicates that there are no more existing elements. The remainder of the sequence is therefore ignored. If the sequence is still producing elements, then those elements must have been created recently and simply picked up by the sequence due to a race condition outside of the control of this method; however, the sequence is still expected to provide notifications for these new elements, so they will not be missed.

item.description: MUST provide a forward-only view of the source.
MUST ensure that element positions within the sequence are unique and absolute.
SHOULD finish observing all existing items and call OnCompleted.

remarks.para: Therefore, if an element is created after the sequence has passed the element's absolute position, it will not be included in the sequence; however, a well-behaving sequence will include it. Furthermore, if an element is observed by the sequence and then subsequently deleted and recreated, it will not be observed a second time.

item.description: MUST generate notifications in a logical order.
SHOULD provide a dynamic, real-time view that includes all changes to the source.

remarks.para: An example of a logical order for the sequence is to include an notification followed by a notification when an element has been added and subsequently removed. An example of an illogical order for this scenario is to include a notification before an notification, which does not accurately reflect the state of changes to the source.
remarks.alert: An illogical ordering of notifications in the sequence voids all guarantees that the reconciliation process makes about the state of the collection when the sequence completes, and also voids all guarantees about the active state of the collection thereafter.
